arcs.title: Beyond a Mod: building a ‘new’ game inside a 1996 classic
arcs.narrative_goal: Give non‑technical viewers emotional footing: this isn’t a cheat-code tweak, it’s a years-long act of authorship and respect—making something new while choosing to be constrained by old hardware on purpose.
topics_to_cover: Kaze’s central promise: “a real N64 game” feeling, not a novelty ROM hack
Why the team self-imposes hard limits (64MB ROM, real console performance) as a creative discipline—not nostalgia cosplay
What ‘respectful but new’ means in practice: rethinking missions, UI, camera, and the overworld structure rather than just swapping levels
The tension between ‘authentic N64’ and ‘modern comfort’ (30/60fps modes, options, quality-of-life)
Kaze’s stance that ROM hacks should stand as complete games for people who never loved SM64 in the first place
b_roll: Close-up of an original N64 booting, then cut to RTYI running on CRT/HDMI-modded console
A simple ‘before/after’ montage: vanilla SM64 → RTYI menu/UI → a modern-looking RTYI scene on real hardware
Visual motif: a 64MB “meter” filling as music/assets are added; intercut with Kaze saying it would feel like ‘cheating’ to exceed it
On-camera interview setup: Kaze holding an N64 controller while describing ‘why this platform’

arcs.title: The Patience Budget: teaching players without killing the magic
arcs.narrative_goal: Make viewers feel the care behind ‘tutorials’: Kaze isn’t building a hard mod for experts—he’s trying to earn trust from players who can quit instantly.
topics_to_cover: “ROM hack patience” vs paid-game patience: why onboarding has to be fast, clear, and optional
Course 1 tutorial bunnies as character-driven teaching (and why ring-gating became necessary)
Camera philosophy: never rotate the camera unexpectedly; human reaction time makes that feel like the game ‘lied’
How playtests (often Zeina’s) directly change difficulty and punishment (e.g., falling into water)
The broader design rule: guidance should be layered and diegetic, not a giant ‘do this now’ arrow
b_roll: Gameplay capture: a tutorial bunny prompt → the ring challenge → coin reward; show failed attempt vs correct action-state success
Split-screen: a forced camera movement example (bad) vs RTYI’s player-controlled camera (good)
Close-up hands on controller as Kaze demonstrates a move the bunny teaches
On-screen text of Kaze quote about “patience budget,” timed to the moment a tutorial prompt appears

arcs.title: The Zoo Catalyst: the level that forced the engine to grow up
arcs.narrative_goal: Turn performance into a story of cause-and-effect: one ambitious level exposed the limits of the old foundation and triggered a multi-year rebuild.
topics_to_cover: Kaze’s claim: “The zoo is the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64” — what was breaking emotionally (lag ruining the fantasy)
What ‘running on real hardware’ actually means: it’s not a checkbox—bugs appear only there
How Biobak’s zoo rework increased ambition (more props/areas) and forced smarter systems
Beta Test 1: what testers loved, what failed (softlock, plane mission), and how outside eyes reshape priorities
The philosophy shift: not ‘add more,’ but ‘make it playable and readable for normal people’
b_roll: Side-by-side: early zoo performance (low FPS) vs improved footage (stable, smooth)
Footage of Kaze testing on real N64, capturing a crash or hardware-only glitch reaction
A zoomed-in “issue map” overlay: softlock spot, plane mission area, glass barrier readability problem
Biobak model turntables of zoo props (aquarium/prison/office) intercut with in-game shots

arcs.title: Making Mario Honest: rewriting collision so the game stops ‘lying’
arcs.narrative_goal: Translate deep technical work into a universal feeling: the difference between a game that ‘betrays you’ and one you can trust.
topics_to_cover: The moment Kaze decides the original collision/step behavior is ‘unusable’ for what RTYI demands
Why better collision isn’t about perfection—it’s about consistency and fairness (removing frame-dependent randomness)
The unintended consequence: changing collision changes beloved exploits (BLJ/PLJ) and speedrun culture
The recurring nightmare: a one-frame landing input crash; how late-stage stability can hinge on tiny timing edges
How this ties back to the central question: rebuilding the classic while staying respectful to how it feels
b_roll: Controller-cam + gameplay: show a frustrating vanilla-style clip/stick moment, then the RTYI version behaving predictably
Whiteboard/overlay animation explaining ‘why sometimes you slip off an edge’ in simple terms (no jargon)
Slow-motion capture of the ‘press A one frame before landing’ moment that can crash (paired with on-screen timestamp)
Kaze in debugger footage/terminal while narrating what he’s chasing (human stakes: “this is why releases take years”)

arcs.title: Oil Rig Strike Comedy: sabotaging workers, staging a story in one level
arcs.narrative_goal: Show RTYI’s signature flavor: a Mario-like world where missions feel like little stories—funny, readable, and mechanically grounded.
topics_to_cover: Theme pivot from volcano to offshore oil rig: chasing a Mario-appropriate palette and mood
The ‘mess with workers’ structure: multiple pranks → overseer Wiggler escalates → star payoff
Why Kaze cuts ideas that aren’t clear or funny enough (oil-barrel gag dropped)
Act 3 tonal shift: Bowser office → eerie empty plaza → monster ‘eats Mario’ transition into boss
Boss design as a setpiece: Oil Blargg + soap as the countermeasure; readability over complexity
b_roll: Storyboard-style recap of Course 11’s three-act flow with in-game clips as each act title appears
Close-ups of the pranks: cement footprints, glass break gag, Womp domino tower chain reaction
Cut to silent plaza moment: music drops out; hold on empty space before boss reveal
Interview intercut: Kaze describing ‘comedy + clarity’ while footage shows him removing a confusing mechanic

arcs.title: Footprints in Wet Cement: a ‘small joke’ that became a technical identity
arcs.narrative_goal: Make the creative process tangible: a playful detail becomes a defining example of inventing new illusions under harsh limits.
topics_to_cover: The initial naive idea (spawn decals) and why it collapses under memory/performance/persistence
The breakthrough: stamping into a texture so prints can be ‘infinite’ and persistent
Design compromise as artistry: circular footprints to avoid rotation complexity—choosing what to simplify without losing the gag
The hidden ‘dirtiness’ detection (sampling pixels) as a way to reward obsessive players without heavy computation
What this reveals about Kaze: he will overbuild for a joke if the joke makes the world feel real
b_roll: Satisfying macro shot: Mario walks through cement, prints appear; then ground pound ‘butt print’ moment
Time-lapse screen recording of the effect evolving from broken/mirrored → correct mapping
Overlay visualization: the sampled pixel pattern used to estimate ‘dirtiness’ (presented as a simple grid)
Reaction clip: Kaze laughing at the gag while simultaneously complaining how much work it is

arcs.title: Two Artists, One Life: Kaze & Zeina’s partnership inside the build
arcs.narrative_goal: Humanize the project: this isn’t just a dev team, it’s a couple building a world together while life changes (and deadlines don’t stop).
topics_to_cover: Their working rhythm: Zeina’s animation deliveries often unblock Kaze’s ‘final’ polish passes (bosses, cutscenes, NPCs)
How feedback happens in real time (pivot fixes, animation pivot points, readability)
Naming Reyna and what it reveals about memory, grief, and meaning while making something playful
New parenthood as a production constraint (brain fog, scheduling, stress) and as motivation
How they protect the relationship when the project is always present (separate offices, boundaries, stream appearances)
b_roll: Home/office B-roll: two workspaces, shared moments, late-night screens (tasteful, non-intrusive)
Zeina animation clips side-by-side with in-game implementation (Wiggler, swinging Yoshi, piano Shy Guy, baby Yoshis)
Audio of Zeina explaining the name Reyna over slow pans of the island overworld at sunset
A calendar montage: major dev milestones intercut with pregnancy/newborn timeline

arcs.title: Biobak’s Reworks: the hidden craft of making ‘places’ people can read
arcs.narrative_goal: Highlight the art/design partnership: RTYI’s leap in quality comes from revisiting old work with a sharper eye—not just making new content.
topics_to_cover: What a ‘rework’ actually means: not cosmetic polish, but changing navigation, readability, and performance cost
The Zoo and Course 1 visual overhauls: adding life while reducing overdraw/material complexity
Course 11 remake integration: when beautiful new geometry breaks collision, fog, or materials—how Kaze and Biobak negotiate fixes
The Course 2 memory crisis (1KB over budget) as a real example of ‘art has weight’ on N64-era constraints
Biobak’s Mario model upgrade: prettier *and* cheaper—why that matters for the whole game
b_roll: Before/after flythroughs: Course 1 and Zoo (older look vs Biobak rework)
Blender viewport of Biobak’s scene → match cut into the same angle in-game
A ‘budget’ graphic: number of materials/triangles/texture memory for old vs new Mario model
On-camera: Biobak explaining one readability decision (color, silhouette, landmark placement) while pointing at footage

arcs.title: Badub and the Soundtrack That Ate the Cartridge
arcs.narrative_goal: Let audiences feel the scale: music isn’t decoration—it’s one of the project’s biggest creative and logistical battles, and it shapes what can exist in the game.
topics_to_cover: The brutal tradeoff: streamed music sounds great but consumes ROM space (the ‘music ate the cartridge’ moment)
How tracks influence level atmosphere and even design decisions (Western level mood shift after a new track arrives)
The dream of an OST cartridge as a ‘souvenir’ that pays collaborators without selling the game
Overworld music as a technical/emotional promise: seamless transitions as you move across the island
Late-stage audio engine rewrite: why Kaze had to rebuild the foundation to support the soundtrack’s ambition
b_roll: A ‘ROM space’ timeline: watch the music portion swell vs the ‘game’ portion
Badub composing/DAW shots (or screen captures) matched to in-game moments where the music defines the scene
Overworld traversal with music crossfading between regions (no cuts, let it breathe)
Close-up of loop-point editing: waveform → the exact moment the loop becomes seamless

arcs.title: Performance Wars: proving miracles on real hardware (and paying for them)
arcs.narrative_goal: Create suspense and credibility: every impressive moment is earned through crashes, profiling, and ruthless tradeoffs—often discovered the hard way on original hardware.
topics_to_cover: Hardware-only failures that change the plan (division-by-zero delay slot crash; floating point exceptions)
The ‘NEMU reproduces N64 crashes’ realization and how it changes debugging speed
Profiling as storytelling: discovering the game spends most of a frame ‘waiting’ and what that implies
Big leaps: F3DEX3 adoption, occlusion planes, collision BVH, compiled render command lists (explained as ‘drawing smarter’)
The psychological arc: Kaze’s obsession with microseconds vs the viewer’s desire for visible content
b_roll: Real N64 test bench: capture card feed, profiler overlay, frame-time numbers changing after a fix
Graphic overlay explaining “drawing less, not faster” with a simple occlusion-plane diagram
A ‘bug museum’ montage: crash screens, broken visuals, then the eventual clean result
Audio of Kaze’s “we killed pointers” moment over fast-cut clips of engine before/after performance

arcs.title: The Feedback Loop: demos, betas, and the ego death of watching players get lost
arcs.narrative_goal: Make audiences root for the game’s accessibility: the team isn’t chasing difficulty clout—they’re chasing clarity, delight, and trust.
topics_to_cover: Why Kaze shifted to single-level demos (Course 1) as a physics/camera testbed, not marketing
The pain of playtest footage: players missing the ‘main path,’ beelining into optional challenges, quitting confused
Course 4 beta: the shock of a disliked mission, the softlock, and what it means to redesign late
The structured questionnaire approach: translating feelings into actionable changes (camera speed, onboarding)
Kaze’s philosophy: respect feelings, don’t blindly implement reasoning; cut content that’s ‘cute but bad’
b_roll: Screen recording of a real playtest moment: player misses the obvious route; then cut to Kaze redesigning signage/geometry
A quick montage of Google Form/questionnaire prompts (camera, controls) over Course 1 gameplay
Before/after of a redesigned entrance or cut section (e.g., cut sub-area due to RAM or confusion)
Interview insert: Kaze watching a clip silently, then explaining what the player *felt*

arcs.title: The Living Overworld: Yoshi’s Island as a world that changes when you do
arcs.narrative_goal: Deliver the documentary’s emotional payoff: the overworld isn’t a menu—it’s the thesis. The island becomes a character that remembers you.
topics_to_cover: The core premise: a full 360° island you can eventually reach everywhere you can see
Diegetic gates that feel like story (lighthouse reveals ghost ship; Dory chained until Bowser 1; message-in-a-bottle hint)
World-state transformations as rewards: rain flower quest, villagers returning, swings filling with Yoshis, melon defense aftermath
Secret design philosophy: deep secrets should become ‘playground rumors,’ not checklist chores (giant coins, Pandora’s box)
How Kaze balances freedom vs sequence-breaking: closing skips, avoiding Wing/Cloud flight in overworld to protect the illusion
b_roll: A continuous island ‘orbit’ shot: camera circles the overworld, landmarks visible, then cuts to later when areas unlock
Lighthouse cutscene: beam rotates, fog clears, ghost ship becomes reachable
Pandora’s box sequence: chest opens → ghost storm VFX → new traversal opportunity
Overworld before/after: empty swings → swings with Yoshi riders after a boss milestone

arcs.title: The Legal Shadow & the Open-Source Promise
arcs.narrative_goal: Raise the stakes: the project is built under a constant, invisible threat—yet Kaze refuses to hide, and plans to give the work away when it’s done.
topics_to_cover: Nintendo risk as lived experience (video takedowns shaping visibility, income, and release strategy)
Why patch-only distribution matters (and why physical cartridges are a line he won’t cross)
The long game: ‘0% Nintendo code’ as both ownership and safety—rewriting systems from scratch
The engine-only release plan: asking the community to audit/improve without leaking the full game
The contingency identity: if taken down, pivot to an original commercial game (Steam via recomp)
b_roll: On-screen montage of removed/claimed video thumbnails (if rights-safe), blurred where needed
A simple animation explaining what a ‘patch’ is: original cart/ROM stays separate; only changes are shared
Kaze deleting/replacing vanilla code segments (tastefully framed as ‘rebuilding foundations’)
Split-screen: “Mario build” vs “original IP build” concept art mock (even as a hypothetical)

arcs.title: Finale Energy: the last course pivots from ‘arcade’ to ‘place,’ and the boss becomes a rescue
arcs.narrative_goal: End with meaning, not just spectacle: the team learns that the final level must feel like a real place, and the final ‘kill the boss’ instinct gives way to healing.
topics_to_cover: Course 15 identity crisis: why ‘arcade minigames’ didn’t feel like Mario 64, and what ‘placeness’ means
The retheme to a Shy Guy space colony/station: function-driven design to guide the player
Boss design turning point: mutated Yoshi as victim; win condition becomes curing, not killing
Tone boundary decisions (body-horror dialed back; mushrooms replacing tumors)
The meta-ending idea: a retro section that becomes a reflective goodbye to SM64 itself
b_roll: Before/after mood board: noisy ‘arcade’ visuals → calmer ‘space colony’ landmarks (homes, crops, water tanks)
Boss prototype footage: portals open, tentacles strike, weak points pop; then ‘healed’ color return moment
Concept sketches or whiteboard notes showing boss loop (telegraph → vulnerable phase → repeat)
A final montage: recognizable SM64 fragments floating in space (the homage) → cut to RTYI’s own island
